Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc

In Lecture 8a it was stated that the principle of mathematical induction has to be taken as an axiom. I would like to offer the following proof of the principle of mathematical induction. Claim: If $$A(n)$$ is a predicate defined on all natural numbers $$n \in \mathbb{N}$$ then we have: $$ A(1) \wedge ( orall n) igl(A(n) \Rightarrow A(n+1) igr) \Rightarrow ( orall n) A(n) $$ Proof: The proof is a proof by contradiction: We assume that the antecedent $$A(1) \wedge ( orall n) igl(A(n) \Rightarrow A(n+1) igr)$$ of the implication given as claim is true, but that the consequent $$ ( orall n) A(n) $$ is false. Now if $$( orall n) A(n)$$ is false, by pure logic, we conclude that there exists a natural number $$c$$ such that $$A(c)$$ is false. Therefore, the set $$ M = \{ n \in \mathbb{N} : eg A(n) \}$$ is not empty, as c is a member of this set. Since $$M$$ is a subset of the set of natural numbers, $$M$$ must have a smallest element $$m$$. As $$m$$ is a member of $$M$$, we have $$ eg A(m)$$. By the antecedent of the implication we are proving we know that $$A(1)$$ holds. Therefore, $$m ot=1$$ and hence $$m > 1$$. Therefore, $$m-1$$ is a natural number. Clearly, $$m-1 ot\in M$$, since $$m - 1 < m$$ and $$m$$ is the smallest element of $$M$$. However, if $$m-1 ot\in M$$, the definition of the set $$M$$ tells us that $$A(m-1)$$ has to be true, for otherwise $$m-1$$ would be a member of $$M$$. But since our second assumption is that $$( orall n) igl(A(n) \Rightarrow A(n+1) igr)$$ holds, we can conclude that $$A(m-1+1) = A(m)$$ must be true also, which contradicts $$ eg A(m)$$. This contradiction proves the claim. $$\Box$$ I am aware that I have traded the PMI for the statement that every non-empty set of natural numbers has a smallest element. However, I consider this latter fact to be much more intuitive than the PMI.

If all reasoning is logical and consist, then the only problem has to be the original assumption. It must be incorrect. Therefore, since the opposite of what you wish to prove is the problem and cannot be true, then the item you wished to prove must be true . This is also called Reduction to Absurdity. Let's keep this in mind: Assume $$\sqrt{2}$$ is rational, since this is the opposite of what we wish to prove. Therefore, it can be represented by integers p/q in their most basic form. They have no common factors. Remember learning fractions, when you had to reduce fractions like 6/8 to 3/4. This is the same thing. It's in it's most simple form. We can use algebra to show that p and q must both be even, which means they have a common factor of 2. Oops. There's the contradiction. They can't be in simplest form and both contain a factor of 2. The only 'flaw' was our original assumption. Therefore, $$\sqrt{2}$$ cannot be rational. It's a 'new type' of number, we call irrational, because it violated the Greek's notion of what numbers were.
